name: 4-hydroxy-3-[(4Z)-4-(3-methoxybenzylidene)-5-oxo-4,5-dihydro-1H-pyrazol-3-yl]-1-methylquinolin-2(1H)-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-647

name: 4-hydroxy-3-[(4Z)-4-(3-methoxybenzylidene)-5-oxo-4,5-dihydro-1H-pyrazol-3-yl]-1-methylquinolin-2(1H)-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-647
Reason: The compound in question contains several functional groups, each contributing to its melting point. The basic unit, a quinoline, would have a moderate melting point, likely in the range of 70-90 degrees Celsius, given the rigidity and planarity of the aromatic system. The 1-methyl group on the quinoline would slightly increase the melting point by adding van der Waals interactions, we can estimate this increase to be about +5. The 4-hydroxy group would significantly raise the melting point due to hydrogen bonding capacity, adding approximately +70 to the melting point. The presence of a benzylidene-5-oxo-4,5-dihydro-1H-pyrazol group is more complex; the additional aromatic ring introduces rigidity and planarity which tends to increase the melting point, possibly by +50, while the 5-oxo group could add another +40 due to its capacity to form strong hydrogen bonds. The 3-methoxy group linked to the benzene ring would not have a significant effect on melting point, so we can neglect it or assume a minor contribution of about +10 due to the extra methoxy mass. In sum, starting with a base of 80 for the quinoline, the additional increases would predict a melting point close to 80 + 5 (methyl) + 70 (hydroxy) + 50 (benzylidene-5-oxo-4,5-dihydro-1H-pyrazol rigidity) + 40 (5-oxo hydrogen bonding) + 10 (methoxy) = 255 degrees Celsius.
